questions.stem: A researcher conducts a psychophysics experiment and finds that a participant can detect a 2-gram difference when holding a 100-gram weight but requires a 4-gram difference to detect a change from a 200-gram weight. This finding is BEST explained by which principle?

options.text: Absolute threshold
Weber's Law
Signal detection theory
Sensory adaptation

questions.explanation: Weber's Law states that the just noticeable difference (JND) is a constant proportion (k) of the original stimulus intensity (delta I / I = k). Here the Weber fraction is 2/100 = 0.02 = 4/200, confirming a constant ratio. The absolute threshold is the minimum detectable stimulus, not a difference. Signal detection theory addresses sensitivity and response bias. Sensory adaptation involves decreased sensitivity to constant stimulation.

questions.stem: A radiologist screening mammograms for breast cancer is advised to adopt a liberal response criterion. Using signal detection theory, what is the MOST likely consequence of this strategy?

options.text: Increased hits and increased false alarms
Increased hits and decreased false alarms
Decreased hits and decreased false alarms
Increased d-prime with no change in response bias

questions.explanation: In signal detection theory, a liberal response criterion (low beta) means the observer has a lower threshold for saying 'yes.' This increases both hits (correctly detecting cancer) and false alarms (incorrectly identifying cancer when absent). A conservative criterion would decrease both hits and false alarms. D-prime reflects sensitivity (ability to discriminate signal from noise) and is independent of response criterion. In clinical screening where missing a true positive is more costly, a liberal criterion is appropriate.

questions.stem: A patient reports that staring at a bright red dot for 30 seconds and then looking at a white wall produces the perception of a green afterimage. This phenomenon is BEST explained by which theory of color vision?

options.text: Trichromatic theory (Young-Helmholtz)
Opponent-process theory (Hering)
Feature integration theory (Treisman)
Frequency theory of color perception

questions.explanation: Afterimages are best explained by opponent-process theory, which proposes that color perception is organized into antagonistic channels (red-green, blue-yellow, black-white). Prolonged stimulation of the red channel fatigues those neurons, so when shifted to a neutral stimulus, the green opponent channel rebounds, producing a green afterimage. Trichromatic theory (three cone types at the retinal level) explains color mixing and certain color blindness but not afterimages. Both theories are correct at different levels of processing. Feature integration theory addresses visual search and attention.

questions.stem: A participant in a dichotic listening task is shadowing a message in the attended ear but suddenly notices their own name spoken in the unattended ear. This phenomenon is BEST explained by which model of attention?

options.text: Broadbent's filter model
Treisman's attenuation model
Deutsch-Norman late selection model
Lavie's perceptual load theory

questions.explanation: Treisman's attenuation model best explains the cocktail party effect. Unlike Broadbent's filter model, which predicts complete blocking of unattended information, Treisman proposed that unattended input is attenuated (turned down) rather than blocked. Highly significant stimuli like one's own name have permanently lowered activation thresholds and can break through even when attenuated. The Deutsch-Norman late selection model would also allow detection but claims ALL information is fully processed semantically, which is overly broad. Lavie's perceptual load theory could explain it under low-load conditions, but the classic explanation is Treisman's model.

questions.stem: A patient with right parietal lobe damage fails to attend to stimuli in their left visual field, eats food from only the right side of the plate, and draws only the right half of a clock. According to Posner's model, which component of spatial attention is impaired?

options.text: Engaging attention at the new location (pulvinar)
Shifting attention to the contralateral field (superior colliculus)
Disengaging attention from the ipsilesional field (posterior parietal cortex)
Filtering irrelevant sensory information (prefrontal cortex)

questions.explanation: Posner's spotlight model identifies three operations of spatial attention: disengaging (posterior parietal cortex), shifting (superior colliculus), and engaging (pulvinar/thalamus). Right parietal lobe damage produces hemispatial neglect -- the patient cannot disengage attention from ipsilesional (right) space to attend to contralateral (left) stimuli. This is a failure of the disengage operation, not shifting or engaging. Prefrontal cortex filtering is not part of Posner's spatial attention model.

questions.stem: Select ALL features that correctly describe RODS (rather than cones) in the visual system.

options.text: Approximately 120 million per retina
Located primarily in the periphery of the retina
High convergence onto ganglion cells producing high sensitivity but low acuity
Concentrated in the fovea for maximum visual acuity
Responsible for scotopic (low-light) vision

questions.explanation: Rods (~120 million) are located primarily in the retinal periphery, function in low-light (scotopic) conditions, and have high convergence (many rods synapse onto a single ganglion cell), which provides high sensitivity but low acuity. Option D is incorrect -- cones, not rods, are concentrated in the fovea, where they provide high acuity through low convergence (near one-to-one mapping). Rods provide black-and-white vision and are critical for night vision.

questions.stem: Select ALL Gestalt principles of perceptual organization that are correctly described.

options.text: Proximity: elements close together are perceived as belonging to the same group
Closure: incomplete figures are perceived as complete; the brain fills in gaps
Common fate: elements moving in the same direction are perceived as a group
Similarity: elements that differ maximally from each other are grouped together
Figure-ground: the visual field is automatically organized into a figure and a background

questions.explanation: Proximity (A), closure (B), common fate (C), and figure-ground (E) are all correctly described. Option D is incorrect because the principle of similarity states that elements that SHARE features (color, shape, size) are grouped together, not elements that differ. Additional Gestalt principles include continuity (good continuation) -- elements arranged along a line or curve are perceived as related.

questions.stem: Select ALL statements that are TRUE about gate-control theory of pain (Melzack & Wall).

options.text: Pain signals can be modulated at the spinal cord level by a gating mechanism
Large-diameter A-beta fibers carrying touch information can close the gate, inhibiting pain
Small-diameter C and A-delta fibers open the gate, facilitating pain transmission
Descending signals from the brain can also close the gate, modulating pain perception
The gate is located in the thalamus and cannot be influenced by psychological factors

questions.explanation: All options except E are correct. Gate-control theory proposes that pain signals are modulated at the spinal cord (substantia gelatinosa), not the thalamus (A). Large A-beta fibers close the gate to reduce pain (B), explaining why rubbing an injury helps. Small C and A-delta fibers open the gate (C). Critically, descending signals from the brain can also close the gate (D), explaining how attention, expectation, emotion, and psychological interventions modulate pain. Option E is incorrect on both counts -- the gate is spinal, not thalamic, and psychological factors DO influence it.

questions.stem: Select ALL correct statements about Feature Integration Theory (Treisman & Gelade, 1980).

options.text: Basic visual features are processed in parallel during the preattentive stage
Focused attention is required to bind features into coherent object representations
Illusory conjunctions occur when features from different objects are incorrectly combined without focused attention
Conjunction search (e.g., finding a red circle among red squares and green circles) is fast and parallel
A unique feature 'pops out' effortlessly in visual search

questions.explanation: Feature Integration Theory proposes two stages: a preattentive stage where basic features are processed automatically and in parallel (A, E), and a focused attention stage where attention binds features into objects (B). Without focused attention, illusory conjunctions can occur (C). Option D is incorrect because conjunction search (requiring combination of two features) is slow and serial, requiring focused attention -- it is feature search (single unique feature) that is fast and parallel ('pop-out').

questions.stem: Select ALL monocular depth cues (cues available from a single eye).

options.text: Linear perspective
Retinal disparity
Interposition (overlap)
Texture gradient
Convergence

questions.explanation: Monocular cues include linear perspective (A), interposition/overlap (C), texture gradient (D), as well as relative size, aerial perspective, and motion parallax. Option B (retinal disparity) is a binocular cue -- each eye receives a slightly different image and the brain uses this difference to compute depth. Option E (convergence) is also binocular -- it refers to the inward turning of both eyes for near objects. Monocular cues are available from a single eye and are the basis for depth perception in paintings and photographs.

questions.stem: For each hearing theory, select the frequency range it BEST explains.
questions.explanation: Place theory proposes that different frequencies cause peak vibration at different locations along the basilar membrane and works best for high frequencies (above ~1,000 Hz). Frequency theory proposes that the basilar membrane vibrates at the same frequency as the sound and works best for low frequencies (below ~500 Hz). The volley principle extends frequency theory by having groups of neurons fire in alternating volleys, effectively coding intermediate frequencies up to ~5,000 Hz. Modern understanding is that these theories are complementary.

questions.stem: For each attention model, select the claim it makes about unattended information.

columns.text: Attenuated but not blocked; important stimuli can break through
Fully processed for meaning; selection occurs at response stage
Processing depends on the perceptual demands of the attended task

questions.explanation: Broadbent's filter model (early selection) claims unattended information is completely blocked based on physical characteristics. Treisman's attenuation model modifies this -- unattended input is attenuated (turned down) but highly relevant stimuli (e.g., one's name) can break through due to lowered thresholds. The Deutsch-Norman late selection model claims ALL information is fully semantically processed and selection occurs at the response stage. Lavie's perceptual load theory integrates both: under high load, selection is early (no spare capacity); under low load, unattended information is processed (late selection).

questions.stem: For each visual phenomenon, select ALL correct characteristics. (Select all that apply in each row.)

columns.text: Failure to perceive a clearly visible stimulus
Occurs when attention is directed elsewhere
Requires a brief visual disruption (e.g., flicker)
Demonstrates that attention is necessary for conscious perception

questions.explanation: Inattentional blindness (e.g., the 'invisible gorilla' experiment) involves failing to perceive a clearly visible stimulus (c1) when attention is directed elsewhere (c2), demonstrating that attention -- not just visual acuity -- is required for conscious perception (c4). It does NOT require a visual disruption. Change blindness involves failing to detect large changes in a visual scene (c1) when the change coincides with a brief visual disruption such as a flicker or saccade (c3), demonstrating that we do not maintain complete representations of scenes (c4). Change blindness does not specifically require attention to be directed elsewhere in the same way.

questions.stem: For each photoreceptor type, select ALL correct characteristics. (Select all that apply in each row.)

columns.text: Located primarily in the retinal periphery
High visual acuity due to low convergence

questions.explanation: Rods are located primarily in the retinal periphery (c2) and function in scotopic/low-light conditions (c4). They provide high sensitivity but low acuity due to high convergence (many rods synapse onto one ganglion cell). Cones are concentrated in the fovea (c1), provide color vision (c3), and have high visual acuity due to low convergence (c5), functioning in photopic (bright light) conditions. There are approximately 120 million rods and 6 million cones per retina.

questions.stem:
Complete the passage about psychophysics concepts.
The [BLANK1] is defined as the minimum intensity of a stimulus that can be detected [BLANK2] of the time. The [BLANK3] is the minimum difference between two stimuli that can be detected 50% of the time. According to [BLANK4], this difference is a constant [BLANK5] of the original stimulus intensity.
questions.explanation: The absolute threshold is the minimum stimulus intensity detected 50% of the time. The difference threshold (JND -- just noticeable difference) is the minimum detectable difference between two stimuli (also 50% criterion). Weber's Law states that the JND is a constant proportion of the original stimulus intensity (delta I / I = k). The Weber fraction (k) is smaller for more sensitive modalities. Note that both thresholds use the 50% detection criterion.

questions.stem:
Complete the passage about the visual pathway and color vision.
The [BLANK1] theory proposes three types of cones sensitive to short, medium, and long wavelengths, explaining color mixing at the [BLANK2] level. The [BLANK3] theory proposes antagonistic color channels (red-green, blue-yellow, black-white), explaining [BLANK4] and operating at the level of retinal ganglion cells and the [BLANK5].
questions.explanation: Trichromatic theory (Young-Helmholtz) explains color mixing through three cone types at the retinal level. Opponent-process theory (Hering) explains afterimages through antagonistic color channels at the post-retinal level -- specifically retinal ganglion cells and the lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN) of the thalamus. Modern understanding holds that both theories are correct at different levels of the visual system: trichromatic processing at the photoreceptor level, opponent processing at the ganglion cell and LGN level.

questions.stem: Analyze the relationship between a clinical observation and its implications.

centerContent.label: Clinical Observation
centerContent.text: Approximately 50% of participants in the 'invisible gorilla' experiment failed to notice a person in a gorilla suit walking through a basketball game when they were counting passes.

options.text: Focused attention on the counting task consumed available processing capacity
The gorilla fell below the absolute threshold for visual detection
Perceptual load of the task prevented processing of the unexpected stimulus
Sensory adaptation to movement caused the gorilla to become imperceptible
Attention -- not just visual acuity -- is necessary for conscious perception
Human visual perception maintains a complete, detailed representation of the entire scene
Clinicians may miss relevant diagnostic information when cognitively overloaded
Unattended stimuli are never processed at any level in the brain

questions.explanation: The invisible gorilla experiment demonstrates inattentional blindness. The counting task consumed processing capacity (l1), consistent with Lavie's perceptual load theory where high-load tasks produce early selection (l3). The gorilla was fully visible (not below threshold -- l2 incorrect) and was a novel stimulus (not adapted to -- l4 incorrect). This demonstrates that attention is required for conscious perception (r1), challenging the intuition that we see everything in our visual field (r2 incorrect). Clinical application: cognitive overload can cause clinicians to miss relevant information (r3). Unattended stimuli may still be processed at some level, just not consciously (r4 incorrect).

questions.stem: Analyze the relationship between a clinical condition and its neurological basis.

centerContent.label: Clinical Condition
centerContent.text: A patient with a right parietal lobe stroke neglects the left side of space -- ignores food on the left side of the plate, fails to groom the left side of the body, and draws only the right half of objects.

options.text: Damage to the posterior parietal cortex disrupts the 'disengage' operation of spatial attention
Destruction of the primary visual cortex (V1) causes complete left visual field blindness
The right hemisphere plays a dominant role in allocating spatial attention to both hemifields
Damage to Broca's area impairs the ability to describe left-sided objects
The patient may be unaware of their deficit (anosognosia) and require structured rehabilitation
The neglect is an attentional deficit, not a sensory or visual loss
Left parietal damage would produce identical contralateral neglect symptoms
The condition is permanent and unresponsive to any rehabilitation efforts

questions.explanation: Hemispatial neglect from right parietal damage involves failure of the disengage operation (l1) per Posner's model. The right hemisphere has a dominant role in spatial attention, attending to both hemifields (l3), which is why right-hemisphere damage produces more severe neglect than left. It is NOT visual field blindness from V1 damage (l2 incorrect) or a language deficit (l4 incorrect). Neglect is an attentional deficit (r2) -- patients can see left-sided stimuli when attention is directed there. Patients are often unaware of the deficit (anosognosia, r1). Left parietal damage produces less severe neglect due to the right hemisphere's bilateral spatial attention (r3 incorrect). Rehabilitation through prism adaptation and other methods can improve symptoms (r4 incorrect).

questions.stem: Highlight the TWO statements that contain errors about signal detection theory.
questions.passage: (1) Signal detection theory recognizes that detection depends on both sensitivity and response criterion. (2) D-prime (d') measures the observer's sensitivity independent of response bias. (3) A false alarm occurs when the observer says 'yes' when the signal is absent, which is equivalent to a Type II error. (4) A conservative response criterion produces fewer false alarms but also more misses. (5) The response criterion (beta) can be shifted depending on the payoff matrix and consequences of different outcomes.

correctHighlights.text: A false alarm occurs when the observer says 'yes' when the signal is absent, which is equivalent to a Type II error.

questions.explanation: Statement 3 contains the error: a false alarm IS when the observer says 'yes' when the signal is absent, but it is equivalent to a Type I error (false positive), NOT a Type II error. A Type II error corresponds to a MISS (saying 'no' when the signal is present, i.e., a false negative). Statements 1, 2, 4, and 5 are all correct. D-prime measures sensitivity independent of bias (2). A conservative criterion reduces false alarms but increases misses (4). Beta shifts based on the payoff matrix (5).

questions.stem: Highlight the TWO statements that contain errors about auditory perception theories.
questions.passage: (1) Place theory proposes that different frequencies cause peak vibration at different locations along the basilar membrane. (2) According to place theory, the base of the basilar membrane responds best to low-frequency sounds while the apex responds best to high-frequency sounds. (3) Frequency theory proposes that the basilar membrane vibrates as a whole at the same frequency as the sound wave. (4) The volley principle extends frequency theory by having groups of neurons fire in alternating volleys. (5) Modern understanding holds that place theory and frequency theory are complementary, with low frequencies coded by firing rate and high frequencies coded by location on the basilar membrane.

correctHighlights.text: According to place theory, the base of the basilar membrane responds best to low-frequency sounds while the apex responds best to high-frequency sounds.

questions.explanation: Statement 2 is reversed: the base of the basilar membrane responds best to HIGH-frequency sounds, and the apex responds best to LOW-frequency sounds. This is the correct tonotopic organization -- it is a commonly tested EPPP fact because the relationship is counterintuitive (base = high, apex = low). Statements 1, 3, 4, and 5 are all correct descriptions of auditory theories.

questions.stem: Arrange the structures of the visual pathway in the correct order from stimulus to cortical processing.

items.text: Primary visual cortex (V1)
Retinal photoreceptors (rods and cones)
Optic chiasm
Lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN) of the thalamus
Retinal ganglion cells
Bipolar cells

questions.explanation: The visual pathway proceeds: (1) Light strikes retinal photoreceptors (rods and cones), which transduce light to neural signals; (2) Signals pass to bipolar cells; (3) Then to retinal ganglion cells, whose axons form the optic nerve; (4) The optic nerve from each eye meets at the optic chiasm, where nasal fibers cross; (5) Signals project to the lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN) of the thalamus; (6) From the LGN, projections go to the primary visual cortex (V1) in the occipital lobe. This pathway is heavily tested on the EPPP.

questions.stem: Arrange the attention models in chronological order of their proposal, from earliest to most recent.

items.text: Lavie's perceptual load theory (1995)
Treisman's attenuation model (1964)
Broadbent's filter model (1958)
Treisman & Gelade's feature integration theory (1980)
Deutsch & Deutsch late selection model (1963)

questions.explanation: The chronological progression of attention models: (1) Broadbent's filter model (1958) -- the first formal early-selection model; (2) Deutsch & Deutsch late selection (1963) -- proposed that all information is fully processed; (3) Treisman's attenuation model (1964) -- modified Broadbent's model to allow attenuated unattended information; (4) Treisman & Gelade's feature integration theory (1980) -- preattentive vs. focused attention stages; (5) Lavie's perceptual load theory (1995) -- integrated early and late selection based on task demands. Understanding this historical progression helps contextualize each model's contributions and limitations.

questions.stem: Consider a visual search experiment comparing feature search (find a red item among green items) versus conjunction search (find a red circle among red squares and green circles) as the number of distractor items increases from 4 to 32.
questions.question: According to Feature Integration Theory, which pattern BEST describes the relationship between set size and reaction time for these two search types?

options.text: Feature search remains flat regardless of set size; conjunction search increases linearly with set size
Both search types increase linearly with set size at equal rates
Feature search increases linearly; conjunction search remains flat
Both search types remain flat regardless of set size

questions.explanation: Feature Integration Theory predicts that feature search (detecting a single unique feature) is processed in parallel during the preattentive stage, so reaction time is independent of set size (flat function -- 'pop-out' effect). Conjunction search (requiring combination of features like red + circle) requires focused attention and serial processing, so reaction time increases linearly as more items must be individually examined. This set-size effect is the key experimental signature distinguishing parallel (preattentive) from serial (attentive) processing.

questions.stem: Consider the relationship between stimulus intensity and perceived magnitude across different sensory modalities as described by Stevens' Power Law (perceived magnitude = k * stimulus intensity ^ n).
questions.question: Which pattern BEST describes how perceived magnitude relates to stimulus intensity for these three modalities according to Stevens' Power Law?

options.text: Electric shock shows an accelerating curve, line length a linear function, and brightness a decelerating curve
All three modalities show identical linear relationships between intensity and perceived magnitude
Brightness shows an accelerating curve while electric shock shows a decelerating curve
All three modalities show decelerating functions (logarithmic) as predicted by Fechner's Law

questions.explanation: Stevens' Power Law describes the relationship between physical stimulus intensity and perceived magnitude using exponents that vary by modality. When the exponent exceeds 1 (e.g., electric shock, n ~ 3.5), perception grows faster than stimulus intensity (accelerating/expansive). When the exponent equals 1 (e.g., line length), the relationship is linear. When the exponent is less than 1 (e.g., brightness, n ~ 0.3), perception grows slower than stimulus intensity (decelerating/compressive). This contrasts with Fechner's Law, which predicts a universal logarithmic relationship for all modalities.

questions.stem: Categorize each processing description as either bottom-up or top-down processing.

items.text: Raw sensory input drives perception without prior knowledge
Context and expectations guide interpretation of ambiguous stimuli
Feature detectors in V1 respond to edges and orientation
Reading words with missing letters by using context clues
Retinal photoreceptors transduce light into neural signals
A clinician's theoretical orientation influences diagnostic perception
Cultural background shapes how ambiguous images are interpreted
Gestalt principles organize raw visual elements into groups

questions.explanation: Bottom-up processing is data-driven: it starts with sensory input and builds toward perception. Examples include retinal transduction (i5), feature detection in V1 (i3), Gestalt grouping of raw elements (i8), and raw sensory input driving perception (i1). Top-down processing is concept-driven: it uses prior knowledge, context, and expectations. Examples include context-based reading (i4), expectations guiding interpretation (i2), clinician theoretical bias (i6), and cultural influences on perception (i7). Most real-world perception involves interaction of both processes.

questions.stem: Categorize each selection model characteristic as describing early selection or late selection theories of attention.

items.text: Unattended information is blocked or attenuated before semantic analysis
All incoming information is fully processed for meaning
Selection occurs based on physical characteristics (e.g., location, pitch)
The bottleneck is at the response/awareness stage, not perception
Broadbent's filter model is the prototypical example
Explains how people can be influenced by unattended semantic content
Treisman's model allows important stimuli to break through attenuation
Deutsch-Norman model is the primary example

questions.explanation: Early selection theories (Broadbent's filter model and Treisman's attenuation model) propose that selection occurs before or during semantic processing: unattended information is blocked/attenuated (i1), selection is based on physical characteristics (i3), Broadbent is the prototype (i5), and Treisman's modification allows important stimuli through (i7). Late selection theories (Deutsch-Norman) propose that all information is fully semantically processed (i2), the bottleneck is at response/awareness (i4), semantic influence from unattended messages is expected (i6), and Deutsch-Norman is the primary example (i8).
